titlePart.entryReference: measuring physical variables of any kind by conversion into electric variables, see Note (4) following the title of class
measuring diffusion of ions in an electric field, e.g. electrophoresis, electro-osmosis,
investigating non-electric or non-magnetic properties of materials by using electric or magnetic methods
indicating correct tuning of resonant circuits

noteParagraph.text: Attention is drawn to the notes immediately following the class title ().

This sub-class deals with (a) measuring all kinds of electric and magnetic variables directly or by derivation from other electric or magnetic variables; (b) measuring all kinds of electric and magnetic properties of materials; (c) testing electric and magnetic devices, apparatus, and networks (e.g. discharge tubes, amplifiers) and measuring their characteristics; (d) indicating presence or sign of current or voltage; (e) equipment for generating signals to be used for carrying out such tests and measurements.
The expression "measuring" is used to include investigating.
The expression "arrangements for measuring" is used to mean "apparatus, circuits, or methods for measuring".

Electric measuring instruments of the general types dealt with in groups , , but specially adapted for measuring a specific variable, e.g. frequency, phase, impedance, are dealt with in the groups relevant to such variables.

titlePart.text: Details of instruments of the types included in groups , , , ,

with magnet external to the coil

operated by elongation of a strip or wire or by expansion of a gas or fluid

for forming a sum or a difference
having more than two moving coils
having both fixed and moving coils, i.e. dynamometers
with iron core magnetically coupling fixed and moving coils

using vibrating reeds, e.g. for measuring frequency

titlePart.entryReference: applicable to electric measuring instruments in general

using modulation of electromagnetic waves, e.g. light beams

Measuring arrangements involving comparison with a reference value, e.g. bridge
Arrangements in which the value to be measured is automatically compared with a reference value
in which the reference value is continuously or periodically swept over the range of values to be measured
in which a force or torque representing the measured value is balanced by a force or torque representing the reference value
